Articles.Content:
It did orbit the comet, but it's no stable orbit. Just let it fly long enough and the orbit will deteriorate and escape the comet once again.

That's what I meant by "a pretty stable orbit". After all, no orbit is 100% stable, anywhere: even the orbits of satellites around the Earth slowly decade.

NASA Deep Space Network is used only as a backup.

Primary station used for communications with the Rosetta is ESTRACK station MalargÃƒÂ¼e.

Gallery: https://www.flickr.com/photos/esa_events/sets/72157628037419233/

Live webcam: http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Operations/ESTRACK_Malarguee_webcam

The stream keeps bogging down here, and is fine after a reload. Not sure what is going on there. I cannot imagine that many people watching already and reloading should not fix that is it was the problem.

Edited November 11, 2014 by Camacha

The steam keeps bogging down here, and is fine after a reload. Not sure what is going on there. I cannot imagine that many people watching already and reloading should not fix that is it was the problem.

It's your connection. Didn't boggle down for me since it went live.

It's your connection.

You'd think, but no other page, clip, file or stream has any trouble loading. That makes it seem a bit unlikely
Probably routing issue. Try grabbing a proxy server to force your traffic along a different route.

Not sure if anyone has posted yet, but amazing pictures: http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2014/11/look-at-the-size-of-that-comet-rosetta-is-chasing-compared-to-a-747/

(No, it's not Jeb having a joy ride. It's a 747 for reference )

Not sure if anyone has posted yet, but amazing pictures: http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2014/11/look-at-the-size-of-that-comet-rosetta-is-chasing-compared-to-a-747/

(No, it's not Jeb having a joy ride. It's a 747 for reference )

Not clear, we need a banana for scale.
Cold gas thrusters on lander are non-operational - from ESA broadcast. Things looking even more complicated now.

Well, that is suboptimal

Nevertheless... Rosetta and Philae: Go for Separation

There's still the twin harpoons. They're going for it.

Fun thing: XKCD is "livestreaming" the event. http://xkcd.com/1446/

The comic changes to a new "frame" every five minutes (an archive can be found at explainxkcd.com)

...And you thought Ions were slow

Sometime in the next hour, Rosetta will perform the Ã¢â‚¬Ëœpre-separation manoeuvreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. This is a thruster burn to place it on course for the separation point, when it will release Philae.

The burn is expected to last about 6 minutes. It will alter RosettaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s velocity by about 0.46m/s and send it heading in towards the comet.

3 min until separation!

Cold gas thrusters on lander are non-operational - from ESA broadcast. Things looking even more complicated now.

Not much they can do about that is there? Makes sense to try anyway.

Not clear, we need a banana for scale.

I don't think ESA has that mod.....

Edited November 12, 2014 by Tw1
Separation confirmed!
Good separation, loving the little celebration they had.
yey...6,5h to go
It's a shame that the landing wasn't an hour or two later, my science teacher would probably let us watch it on the projector while we were working.

What they did and want to do:

Translation:

02:35 - Ground control station gave the Go!

04:35 - Activated first science instrument of Philae

08:00 - Orbiter control center gave the Go!

08:21 - Activated the science instruments MUPUS, SESAME and CONSERT*

09:35 - Philae undocked

09:44 - Deploying landing gear // unconfirmed because of signal delay

11:35 - Start communication between lander and orbiter

15:35 - First image will be shoot

16:33 - Landing

20:30 - End of communication between lander and orbiter

Time zone is UTC+1, signal delay is ~30 minutes.

* MUPUS - MUlti-PUrpose Sensors for Surface and Sub-Surface Science

SESAME - Surface Electric Sounding and Acoustic Monitoring Experiment

CONSERT - COmet Nucleus Sounding Experiment by Radiowave Transmission

Edited November 12, 2014 by *Aqua*

*crossing fingers!

I hope everything go well kamarades!
1 minute till loss of contact for the time Rosetta makes an escape burn. Contact will be regained at 11:58 CET.

Well, that is suboptimal

Nevertheless... Rosetta and Philae: Go for Separation

There's still the twin harpoons. They're going for it.

Captain Ahab: From hell's heart I stab at thee; for hate's sake I spit my last breath at thee. Ye damned comet!
1:50 to the part about thruster. Readings are not looking good, but the final proof will be at the touchdown, when they'll try to run the motor. Without it - landing will be very difficult.
Today's XKCD is essentially a live feed in Randall's own unique style.
They got signal back from Rosetta - contact established with Philae. We should get first data soon (including pictures).
Contact was re-established
